Poverty and Death in the Indonesian Gold Country
When Bardina Degei cooks the dinner she does not use a cook .
It rarely uses a pot .

In its wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually lays a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly in the fireplace .
After half an hour , the cartilever is washed with ice , unwashed hands and swallowed .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , for example washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a homeless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , no fields were assigned to her .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , working late can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 17 o 'clock ,  she says .

It is a rare glimpse into the daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted to Indonesia after a controversial referendum in 1969 , when only 1,026 elders were supposed to vote by a public handpicked before the occupying forces .
An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against Jakarta ’ s government , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
The journey includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and then a morning 5-hour drive with the rental car .
There is no public transport .
The town of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences , and of corrugated roofs transformed by rust into various yellow brown tones .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , revered Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei and hints at her lively , hand-woven Turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
We used to have only leaves on our bodies .
Papua is Indonesia 's poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of the worst rates of infant mortality and literacy in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s gold country .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Freeport McMoran of Phoenix , lies just 60 miles from Paniai , a high-land province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport lost $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
In addition , Papua has natural resources worth an estimated USD 78 billion .
However , these riches are a source of misery for the Papua people who ensure that Indonesia 's powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .
A 2005 investigation in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid local military personnel and units nearly $ 20 million between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten this golden goose and are relentlessly treated .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured , and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal country in the 1970 ’ s became genocide under the Asia-Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We will lose everything ,  says a 2016 report by Erzdiözese Brisbane , which contains reports of atrocities of the previous year , such as unlawful executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal suppression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because every week incidents happen ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have intensified as Papua ’ s resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic development is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese warnings sell fried chicken and gado , a mixed vegetables served with peanut sauce .
Local people are fighting to stay here .

The migrants have begun selling chickens and vegetables on the traditional market cheaper than the local Papua ,  Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai native who moved to the provincial capital Jayapura to work .
It has cost the native Papua - the Mama-Mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market .
The Indonesian President Joko Widodo , known as Jokowi in the popular community , promised to address the inequalities and legal injuries in Papua during his campaign in 2014 .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the total 29 districts of Papua - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But in Papua little has changed , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts are broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai had a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children outside and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The shocked children told them that they should turn their spotlights on .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and later returned with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk , chased and beat the group with their rifles , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired in the group of children .
One child , 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was so badly beaten that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set fire and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered on a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command center to demand justice .
